title: 104_s1979
content: The Act titled "Work Incentive and Self-Sufficiency Act of 1996" includes a return-to-work program for Social Security Disability Income beneficiaries. The "Work Incentive and Self-Sufficiency Act of 1996" includes a provision that amends the Social Security Act to reduce an individual's disability insurance benefit based on excess earnings, with specific rules for calculating the reduction. The "Work Incentive and Self-Sufficiency Act of 1996" amends the Social Security Act to reduce disability insurance benefits based on excess earnings, with specific rules for calculation. This includes a provision for reducing benefits for blind or disabled individuals receiving benefits under title XVI before reducing benefits under title II. Amendments are made to sections 223(a)(2) and 1611(b) of the Act. Additionally, the Act repeals the Trial Work Period and Extended Period of Eligibility under section 222. Eligibility changes are made to the Social Security Act, including the repeal of certain subsections and amendments to disability cessation and termination month definitions. Amendments are made to sections 202(e)(1) and 202(f)(1) of the Social Security Act, removing references to section 223(e) and defining the termination month as the third month following the month in which disability ceases. Amendments to the Social Security Act redefine the termination month as the third month after disability ceases. Continued eligibility for Medicare benefits for disabled individuals with annual adjusted gross income below $15,000. Amendment to Section 226(b) of the Social Security Act allows individuals with disabilities to continue receiving benefits if their annual adjusted gross income is below $15,000, even after their entitlement or status as a qualified railroad retirement beneficiary has ended. MEDICARE BUY-IN PROVISIONS FOR DISABLED INDIVIDUALS WHO HAVE EXHAUSTED OTHER ENTITLEMENT AND FOR THOSE NOT OTHERWISE ELIGIBLE FOR MEDICARE BENEFITS. Change in Payment for Hospital Insurance Benefits for Disabled Individuals Who Have Exhausted Other Entitlement under the Social Security Act. Monthly premium for individuals shall be 10 percent of adjusted gross income or the premium determined under section 1818(d). Provisions of section 1818 relating to premiums apply to individuals enrolled under this section. Title XVIII of the Social Security Act is amended to include a new section after section 1818A. Title XVIII of the Social Security Act is amended to include a new section after section 1818A, providing hospital insurance benefits for disabled individuals who are not otherwise eligible. Title XVIII of the Social Security Act is amended to include a new section, 1818B, allowing individuals under 65 with disabling impairments or blindness to enroll in the insurance program if they exceed the substantial gainful activity amount and are not entitled to other benefits under this part. Enrollment is subject to regulations and must be done in the prescribed manner. Enrollment in the insurance program for individuals under 65 with disabling impairments or blindness is subject to regulations. There is a general enrollment period from January 1 to March 31 each year. The coverage period begins the month after enrollment and continues until termination notice is provided by the Secretary. Enrollment in the insurance program for individuals under 65 with disabling impairments or blindness is subject to regulations. Termination of coverage can occur if the individual no longer meets certain conditions, such as no longer wishing to participate, becoming eligible for hospital insurance benefits, or nonpayment of premiums. The Secretary may provide a grace period of up to 90 days, extendable to 180 days with good cause. Termination under this section results in simultaneous termination of any affected coverage under other parts. Premiums for enrollment under this section must be paid to the Secretary as prescribed by regulations and deposited in the Treasury to the credit of the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund. These premiums are payable from the first month of coverage until the individual's death or termination of coverage, with exceptions for certain months. Premiums for Supplementary Medical Insurance Benefits for Disabled Individuals Who Have Exhausted Other Entitlement and for Disabled Individuals Who Are Not Otherwise Eligible are outlined in section 1839 of the Social Security Act. Monthly premiums are required for eligible individuals under specific circumstances. The monthly premium for individuals eligible for benefits under part A is determined based on adjusted gross income, established by the Administrator of the Health Care Financing Administration on a sliding scale from 50% to 100% of the monthly actuarial rate for enrollees age 65 and over. The monthly premium for individuals age 65 and over is determined based on adjusted gross income, established on a sliding scale from 50% to 100% of the monthly actuarial rate for enrollees. Initial open enrollment requirements are also outlined for disabled individuals who are not otherwise eligible. The Secretary will establish the initial enrollment period for individuals entitled to enroll for benefits under section 1818B of the Social Security Act. Additionally, section 1862(b)(1)(B)(i) is amended to include individuals entitled to enroll for benefits under this title under section 1818B. SEC. 5. Medicare/Medicaid integration demonstration project. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct demonstration projects to show how States can use funds from the Medicare and Medicaid programs to provide cost-effective care for chronically-ill elderly and disabled beneficiaries through integrated systems of care emphasizing case management and prevention. The Secretary will conduct demonstration projects using Medicare and Medicaid funds to provide cost-effective care for chronically-ill elderly and disabled beneficiaries through integrated systems of care. States can participate in up to 10 projects without requiring eligible individuals to join. Each State or coalition must submit an application to conduct a project. The Secretary will approve or deny applications for demonstration projects within 90 days. Payments will be made to designated entities based on the Federal capitated payment rate for providing care to chronically-ill elderly and disabled individuals. Each State, or coalition of States, designates entities to receive payments for providing care to chronically-ill elderly and disabled beneficiaries eligible for Medicare and Medicaid services. Entities must meet quality and coverage standards. State payments are based on the Federal capitated payment rate. Entities designated by a State or coalition of States receive payments for providing care to chronically-ill elderly and disabled beneficiaries eligible for Medicare and Medicaid services. Payments are based on the Federal capitated payment rate, with a budget neutrality requirement to ensure Federal payments do not exceed what would have been made under the Medicare and Medicaid programs. The demonstration projects under this section will be conducted for a 5-year period, subject to annual review and approval by the Secretary. The Secretary may terminate any project not in compliance with approved terms. Quality standards will be established for monitoring these projects. Quality standards for demonstration projects under this section will include reporting requirements such as a project description, beneficiary satisfaction analysis, service quality evaluation, and Medicare/Medicaid savings description. The Medicare and Medicaid coverage data bank under Section 13581 of the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1993 is repealed. The Social Security Act will be applied as if this section had not been enacted. The amendments made by sections 2, 3, and 4 will apply to taxable years ending after 1996.
